title: Vendor Requirements Guide
description: Select the type of vendor you are sourcing to see the required tier and what you should request before onboarding.

q_vendor_type.text:
What type of vendor are you sourcing?
Choose the option that best matches the vendor's role.

No data and no system access (e.g. stati.explanation:
Tier: ðŸŸ¢ Tier 3 â€“ Low Risk

The vendor does not access systems and does not process your data.

---

What to request:

- Basic contract
- Pricing details
- Delivery or service terms

---

Not required:

- No Data Processing Agreement (DPA)
- No Service Level Agreement (SLA)
- No security questionnaires
- No SOC 2 or ISO 27001 evidence

---

Examples:

- Stationery supplier
- Catering services
- Cleaning company
- Uniform suppliers
- Furniture providers

---

Official guidance and references:

- ICO Data Protection Basics: https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/data-protection-basics
- UK Procurement Policy Notes (PPNs): https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/procurement-policy-notes

---

Why this matters:

These vendors create almost no security or privacy exposure. The aim is to keep processes lightweight so procurement isn't slowed down by unnecessary checks.

Low/internal data only (e.g. training to.explanation:
Tier: ðŸŸ¡ Tier 2 â€“ Medium Risk

The vendor handles internal-only or low-sensitivity data.

---

What to request:

- Light SLA (response times)
- High-level security or privacy policy
- Data storage region (country/region)
- Data retention period
- DPA only if personal data is involved

---

Not required:

- SOC 2 or ISO 27001 as mandatory evidence
- Large security questionnaires
- Full DR/BCM documentation

---

Examples:

- Staff training platforms
- Internal survey systems
- Departmental scheduling tools
- Administrative SaaS utilities

---

Official guidance and references:

- ICO Controllers and Processors: https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/uk-gdpr-guidance-and-resources/controllers-and-processors
- ICO Data Sharing Guidance: https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/uk-gdpr-guidance-and-resources/data-sharing
- NCSC Cloud Security Principles: https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/cloud

---

Why this matters:

These vendors touch internal or administrative data but pose limited organisational risk. Baseline data handling and storage checks ensure responsible use without overburdening suppliers.

Personal data or integration (e.g. HR, C.explanation:
Tier: ðŸŸ  Tier 1 â€“ High Risk

The vendor processes personal data or integrates with core systems.

---

What to request:

- Data Processing Agreement (DPA)
- List of sub-processors
- SLA with uptime and support commitments
- ISO 27001, SOC 2, or penetration test evidence
- MFA and role-based access control information
- Data flow diagram
- Incident notification commitment (e.g. 48 hours)
- Exit and secure deletion plan

---

Examples:

- HR and payroll systems
- CRM platforms
- Timekeeping or attendance software
- SaaS tools requiring user logins
- API service providers handling personal or operational data

---

Official guidance and references:

- ISO/IEC 27001 Information Security Standard: https://www.iso.org/standard/27001
- AICPA SOC 2 Trust Services Criteria: https://www.aicpa-cima.com
- ICO Security of Processing (Article 32): https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/uk-gdpr-guidance-and-resources/security
- NCSC Zero Trust Architecture: https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/zero-trust
- NCSC Logging and Monitoring: https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/logging-and-monitoring

---

Why this matters:

When vendors handle personal data or integrate technically, both privacy and cyber risk increase. These requirements provide assurance that the vendor maintains mature security controls and transparent data flows.

Critical/high-impact service (e.g. cloud.explanation:
Tier: ðŸ”´ Tier 0 â€“ Critical

The vendor provides a core service or has privileged access where failure would disrupt operations.

---

What to request:

- DPA (if personal data is processed)
- Strong contract with mandatory security clauses
- SOC 2 Type II and/or ISO 27001 certification
- Penetration test results or assurance report
- Security architecture overview
- MFA and privileged access controls
- SLA with high uptime guarantees
- BCM and DR documentation with testing evidence
- Incident notification within 24 hours
- Detailed off-boarding and data deletion plan

---

Examples:

- AWS, Azure, GCP
- Enterprise-wide identity providers (Okta, Entra)
- Core clinical or business platforms
- Payment processors
- Managed service providers with admin access

---

Official guidance and references:

- NCSC Supply Chain Security: https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/supply-chain-security
- NCSC Cloud Security Principles: https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/cloud
- ISO 22301 Business Continuity Standard: https://www.iso.org/standard/75106
- PRA/FCA Operational Resilience Requirements: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation
- EU DORA (Digital Operational Resilience Act): https://finance.ec.europa.eu/regulation-and-supervision/financial-services-legislation/digital-finance/dora_en

---

Why this matters:

Critical vendors create organisational dependency. A failure, outage, or breach could halt operations or create regulatory exposure. These references and requirements ensure resilience, incident readiness, and accountability.
